newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Tapie on trial for tax fraud over yacht.
newsitem.headline: France's Tapie on trial for tax fraud over yacht.

text.p: Bankrupt French business tycoon Bernard Tapie, who is already serving an eight-month jail term for rigging a soccer match, appealed on Thursday against a six-month sentence for tax evasion in the management of his luxury yacht.

In his first public appearance since he was jailed almost two months ago, the flamboyant former minister appealed against the sentence for passing off the majestic 74-metre (245 ft), four-mast ship Phocea as a means of promoting his business, although he was its only beneficiary.
Television crews and photographers were banned from the courtroom.

Tapie, 54, has tumbled from political and business stardom since 1993, when he rigged a league match to give his team Marseille an easy game before their successful European Cup final against AC Milan.
The $11 million yacht, which at the height of Tapie's rise to wealth and fame was moored proudly in the old port of Marseille, has been seized and is on sale.
Tapie has been declared bankrupt and ineligible for public office and banned from running a business. He has lost his seats in the French and European parliaments.
His Paris mansion has also been seized and his furniture was sold earlier this week, netting 4.2 million francs ($740,000) for his creditors.
